project_head:
THERE IS A NEW GENERATION OF VOICES SHAPING OUR NATIONAL CONVERSATION ABOUT BEING BLACK IN THE USA.

WE WANT TO CONNECT YOU TO SOME OF THESE VOICES.

#INTHEIRWORDS
title: #InTheirWords
credits_intro: There is a new generation of voices shaping our national conversation about being black in the USA. This is a space for those voices to be heard. Instead of taking a traditional approach to reporting their stories, we decided to step aside and let people tell their stories #intheirwords. The goal is to start an authentic dialogue about the state of civil rights today and to deepen our collective understanding.
tag_text: WHAT TOPICS WOULD YOU LIKE TO EXPLORE
share_intro: YOUR TURN. CONTINUE THIS CONVERSATION BY SHARING THIS VIDEO.

videos.video_quotes: "Beauty really is a woman who is feeling amazing."
videos.intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.
videos.videodescription: Carrie Hammer talks about beauty and confidence.

videos.video_quotes: "I know very few people who can't get on board with that message."
videos.intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.
videos.videodescription: Carrie Hammer  says the definition of feminism is equal rights for men and women.

videos.video_quotes: “Feminism is for everybody…”
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.videodescription: Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. talks about the tension between white progressive liberal feminism and feminism rooted in the experiences of women of color.

videos.video_quotes: “They expected…women to sound like men…"
videos.questionasked: Was there a time when you felt aware of your gender?
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.videodescription: Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. talks about seiminary school and the expectation that women students conform into the stereotypical religious leader - a white male.

videos.video_quotes: "How do we balance caring for our families, our careers...”
videos.questionasked: What challenges do women face today?
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.videodescription: Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. talks about the challenges of juggling her family life with her career.

videos.video_quotes: “Some like to call me a plus size model, some a fat model…”
videos.questionasked: Tell us about your career
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham talks about her modeling career and how she’s turned the negative connotation of a “plus size” model into an opportunity to prove that curves are in.

videos.video_quotes: “It’s really hard to teach confidence…”
videos.questionasked: You speak at high schools to teenage girls about body image, what advice to you give them?
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.tags: young women, body image, body activist
videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham talks about speaking to groups of young women about body image and embracing their curves and bodies.

videos.video_quotes: "We are standing up for rights, for equality..."
videos.questionasked: What does feminism mean to you?
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.tags: feminism, What feminism means to me, equality
videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham says feminism isn't just for women but equality for all people.

videos.video_quotes: "Is it because I’m a woman or I’m just not good enough?"
videos.questionasked: Can you tell me about a time your gender impacted your career or pursuing your dreams?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.tags: Women, Journalism, career advancement, gender bias
videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman says gender bias is more subtle in the workplace today. She says women often wonder if they are underqualified or "crazy" when in reality they may be experiencing setbacks in their career because they are women.

videos.video_quotes: “It’s trying to actively remedy some of those power imbalances. "
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman talks about being a feminist. She says it’s a way of looking at the world and differs for everyone.

videos.video_quotes: “It’s also an issue that effects other people in the workplace who don’t have kids.”
videos.questionasked: What issues effect gender equality in the work place?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedmannn. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.tags: gender equality, paid family family medical leave
videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman says a big step for gender equality is paid family medical leave for all workers.

videos.video_quotes: “During my lifetime I’ve seem so much progress.”
videos.questionasked: Have you seen progress for women in your lifetime?
videos.intro: Meet Emily May. She co-founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.
videos.tags: Sexual harrassment in the workplace, progress
videos.videodescription: Emily May  talks about the progress she has seen for women in the workplace in her lifetime, and says the future battles have to do with how women are treated outside of work.

videos.video_quotes: “ Feminism...is about the right to be you.”
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Emily May. She co-founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.
videos.videodescription: Emily says that feminism isn't just about men and women, but the right of all people to feel comfortable in the world.

videos.video_quotes: "You wonder if going back to work would help your family.”
videos.questionasked: From your own experience or from hearing from friends, do you think there’s pressure for moms to say home with their kids or pressure to work outside the home?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.videodescription: Renee talks about the pressures for men and women to juggle providing for their family and having enough time at home.

videos.video_quotes: “We have intuitions and instincts, that are exclusive to us.”
videos.questionasked: What advice do you give your daughters?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.videodescription: Renee says that because women can bring life into the world, she tells her daughters that being a woman comes with a lot of responsibility.

videos.video_quotes: “We need to be equal, but not expected to be the same.”
videos.questionasked: Do you think there are certain issues women are concerned about?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.videodescription: Renee says that eqaulity is one of the biggest issues women are concerned about.

videos.video_quotes: "While the numbers are low they're not zero."
videos.questionasked: How can we increase diversity in tech fields?
videos.intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera, the founder of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
videos.videodescription: Natalia talks about highlighting the diversity that already exists in addition to creating more diversity in the tech industry.

videos.video_quotes: "I'm my own boss, I have my own agency..."
videos.questionasked: What advice to you give to women starting their own business?
videos.intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera, the founder of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
videos.videodescription: Natalia talks about the joys of being her own boss.

videos.video_quotes: "You should feel empowered to make the choice that makes sense for you..."
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.videodescription: Jocleyn

videos.video_quotes: "We want people to be paid fairly."
videos.questionasked: What is the gender pay gap?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.tags: pay gap, minorities, women of color
videos.videodescription: Jocleyn

videos.video_quotes: "We all come to the table with different, individual talents."
videos.questionasked: What advice would you give to younger women?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.videodescription: Jocelyn tells young women to be confident and bold.

videos.video_quotes: "I'm sort of surprised by the fact that it didn't affect me."
videos.questionasked: Was there a time when your gender felt like an obstacle?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.videodescription: When Jocelyn was a young girl people told her she couldn't be a lawyer because of her race and gender.

videos.video_quotes: "There's so many judgments that are often leveled against women."
videos.questionasked: How can women help other women?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.videodescription: Jocelyn says we should respect the different choices women make for themselves.

videos.video_quotes: “It was not considered the appropriate thing for women to do…”
videos.questionasked: When you began in the science field what were some of the main barriers that women faced?
videos.intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.
videos.tags: equlity, STEM fields, science, marine biology
videos.videodescription: Sylvia talks about the attitude towards women in science when she started her career. She says she applied to lead the first team of women aquanauts in 1970 because it didn’t say on the application that women should not apply. So she did.

videos.video_quotes: “Today in positions of leadership women continue to be in the minority.”
videos.questionasked: Have you seen progress for women in your lifetime?
videos.intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.
videos.tags: STEM fields, women in the workplace, glass ceiling, leadership
videos.videodescription: Sylvia Earle says that women still face hardships in obtaining leadership roles in the workplace. She says women leaders provide a more collaborative approach to leadership.

people.person_bio: Ann Friedman, 33, is a magazine journalist and the former executive editor of GOOD magazine. Friedman writes about the Internet, politics, culture and gender. She also co-hosts the podcast "Call your Girlfriend" with Aminatou Sow.
people.person_intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.

people.person_bio: Ashley Graham, 27, is known for her work as a lingerie model for the plus-size clothing retailer Lane Bryant. She has been featured in magazines like Vogue, Sports Illustrated and Glamour. Graham considers herself to be a body activist and encourages women to embrace their curves.
people.person_intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.

people.person_bio: Jocelyn Frye, 51, is senior fellow at the Center for American Progress and an expert on pay equity and women's issues. She served in the White House as a deputy assistant to President Obama and a director of policy for Michelle Obama with a special focus on women and children.
people.person_intro: Meet Jocelyn Frey. She's an expert on pay equity and directed policy on women's issues for Michelle Obama.

people.person_bio: Emily May, 33, co-founded Hollaback!, an organization that works to end street harrassment and empower women who are catcalled on the street. The group's website and mobile app give women and men an outlet to share experiences and find support.
people.person_intro: Meet Emily May. She founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.

people.person_bio: Angela Hucles is a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer and a two-time World Cup bronze medalist. She also played professional soccer player for the Boston Breakers. Hucles is now president of the Women's Sports Foundation and advocates getting young women involved in sports.
people.person_intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.

people.person_bio: Carrie Hammer, 29, is a clothing designer specializing in career clothes for women. She started her self-titled clothing line after being disappointed in the professional clothes available to women. She hosts an annual show at New York Fashion Week called 'Role models not runway models' that celebrates women who are at the top of their field professionally.
people.person_intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.

people.person_bio: Natalia Oberti Noguera, 31, is the founder and CEO of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
people.person_intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera. She founded Pipeline Fellowship, an organization that creates capital for female-led startups.

people.person_bio: Mihee Kim-Kort, 37, is an ordained Presbyterian minister. She's the author of several books including Making Paper Cranes: Toward an Asian American Feminist Theology and Yoked: Stories of a Clergy Couple in Marriage, Family, and Ministry, which she wrote with her husband Andrew Kort.
people.person_intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an author and ordained Presbyterian minister.

people.person_bio: Sabrina Hersi Issa, 31, founded Be Bold Media, a digial company that focuses on global advocacy and media innovation. She advocates for women in technology.
people.person_intro: Meet Sabrina Hersi Issa. She founded Be Bold Media.

people.person_bio: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle , an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, lecturer and Explorer-in-Residence at National Geographic. Earle has logged more than 7,000 hours underwater, and led the first team of women aquanauts during the Tektite Project in 1970.
people.person_intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.

people.person_bio: Renee Dixon, 48, is a mother of three. She homeschools her children and works as a realtor.
people.person_intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids.
